review_title: Been a great place for me, might not be for everybody
pros: Hard work is well rewarded especially via stock for development org. The benefits are excellent and comprehensive. There’s plenty of opportunity to learn and apply your skills. With a great immediate manager and enough buffer from the ones that manage by f-bombs, it’s a great environment.
cons:
Management can slow things down and tend to get in the way. Many upper level managers/vps clearly haven’t taken the required courses on harassment and micro aggressions (if they have, they’ve learned little). While stock awards are generous to top performers, bonus and raise rounds in recent years pale in comparison to 90s-early 2000/“s. 

The company is overloaded with way too many “customer-care” type people that contribute little but hound those actually doing work for continual status updates. These roles are duplicated across various divisions which makes it even worse. Dealing with these people is by far the most miserable part of the job for me.  I’m pretty sure bonuses and raises would still be plentiful if these people weren’t consuming so much payroll.

pros: I love working here. Lots of tools and resources at our disposal. It's exciting having the opportunity to work for such a large company, which means there are lots of opportunities for movement within.
cons: No annual salary increases (tied to performance or even small cost of living increases). Kind of a bummer, and honestly pretty surprising when I started. There is also no direct path to grow within your team. I love what I do, but when a Senior level team member left, it seemed to open a spot for advancement (for myself or another member of my team). However, we were informed that since the role wouldn't change all that much from what we do now, Oracle does not provide title changes/promotions within the same team (thought process being it's kind of a lateral move, increased compensation without any real increase in responsibilities). I don't want to have to change teams each time I want to progress in my career.

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Boston, MA
pros:
Salary was fine, but there were none of the perks you find at other big tech companies like Facebook or Google--no free snacks, have to pay for the gym onsite, etc. 
You don't have to work very hard as a BDC/sales development representative/whatever they're calling the role nowadays. But you are VERY dependent on your sales rep to "help" you find opportunities.
cons: I wish people had warned me about the fratty culture. Oracle sales purportedly hires "leaders", which includes former college athletes, student council members, etc. and ultimately results in a lot of former fraternity/sorority members being hired. The environment is quite literally collegiate, in that all the bonding activities involve drinking and people act like they're still living out their frat-bro days. It doesn't help that they hire in such large batches (I started with 100 people in the Austin office) and with so many people fresh out of college, which leads to the same cliquey-ness and gossip that freshman year of college entailed.

review_title: It all depends on your group/team
pros: Oracle can be a 40 hour a week gig or notably less for some teams. If you are lucky, you have good managers and management that will look out for you. If not, the overall culture is competitive and stressful.
cons:
Some teams work a ridiculous number of hours per week (50-60 minimum every week), and people feel like an unimportant cog in a machine.

There's also a large contractor workforce of second-class workers. It leads to many disgruntled people who are worried about losing their job based on a whim or one person's opinion.

There are too many people looking to comment negatively on your work/projects and get ahead themselves. It's as if the team or larger company doesn't get ahead by other teams succeeding.

job_title: Senior Technical Program Manager%2FProject Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: I’ve been able to move around to different teams and get a lot of diversified experience, as well as move when the situation wasn’t ideal. It’s fairly disorganized, like a teenager who still doesn’t know quite what to do but means well and has the idea. I see this as a pro because there is a ton of opportunities to shine if you’re willing to work for it.
cons:
Disorganized and lack of processes on the most critical levels - the everyday stuff. Management has a lot of churn - it’s like the weather in Seattle. If you don’t like it, just wait 5 minutes. 
One of the real cons of this is that when it comes to review time, oops, you barely know your boss. You worked hard for the last one but now they’re gone. Start over, and hope next year someone will recognize your body of work.

review_title: Good first job that can lead to better things if you look outside of the company.
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Austin, TX
pros:
-Great opportunity for someone fresh out of college with little experience
-You're starting with a class of 100s of other people around your age, easy to make friends
-Pretty easy to be successful. Most of the class is frat bros/sorority girls who are really there more to socialize and have fun than they are to work. Nothing wrong with that, but if your goal is to be good at your job and make a lot of money you can rank at the top every quarter if you're willing to put in just a little effort. 
-Honestly really good pay for what is essentially a glorified telemarketing job.
cons:
-Job is not fulfilling at all
-Micromanagement
-Lack of transparency, KPIs that don't make sense
-Constant changes, your job is more about fake metrics (# of calls per day, quick tours) than it is actual sales (creating legitimate opportunities)
-Lack of promotion opportunities. A lot of the promotions to move up from BDC look like promotions in title, but actually end up paying less

job_title: Business Development Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
There was very good access to training and further education. There were good progression opportunities, with well-defined paths for moving into more senior roles (However you had to wait x amount of months before you could progress again). You also get to work alongside some very competent and fun colleagues.

Compensation wasn't great but they did have fantastic benefits including health insurance and generous pension contributions.
cons: When I was there the company was making a lot of structural changes which meant day-to-day work was quite disorganized. There were so many acquisitions it was hard to fully grasp what products did and how to position them. They had a big hiring push so everyone's territories were squeezed and sales targets for most were often unrealistic. Pay scales and progression were very rigid so you had to follow the well-beaten path rather than having options open up if you were performing well.

review_title: Good Benefits, Terrible Management, Very siloed
pros:
Great benefits - one of the only companies that pay full health cover for employees and their family.

Allow remote/ flexible working.
cons: Extremely siloed. Different parts of the business end up competing against each other for the same clients. There is a sense that everyone is out for themselves. When solvable issues are raised to management, nothing is done to change incentives or process, so issues persist. Oracle claims to be customer centric, but they have a low accountability culture toward both clients and staff, and can be outright aggressive toward clients on contract negotiations. The good people either leave or become extremely jaded.

review_title: Solid company depending on what you’re looking for.
pros: Started Oracle right out of college. Been here over 3 years. Really great learning experience for me. Looks good on the resume. Base pay is decent, and depending on where you go some solutions are better than others and have more potential to hit or go above OTE. Research what product you’re selling and try to follow the money. The leadership is working to become more agile and they definitely value their employees, even though it is a huge company. Some top talent teaching you and helping you sell. Great work life balance.
cons: Company moves slow, lots of tools can make it tricky to priotize which ones you should actually be using. Lot of internal programs that seem to never gain much traction. Can be hard to get a technical resource at times.

review_title: good remote work, but a lot of management layers who don't do very much
pros:
- good remote work from home
- stable environment
- easy to standout (if you just work a little harder, you are a rockstar)
- competitive compensation and good benefits
cons:
- a lot of management tiers with majority not doing anything
- management like to hear themselves talk, but don't do very much
- everyone is jockeying for credit; managers take credit for team members
- a lot of meetings with a lot of talking but no action
- slow to take action; very slow organization
- people like their processes; are not open to new ideas ("don't break it if it is not broken")
- a lot of people "phoning it in"
